qas.question: Who establishes the doctrines of the Jehovah's Witnesses?
What do the Jehovah's Witnesses religion not tolerate any of?
What happens to members who disagree with the religion's teachings?
Why should the counsel received from the Governing Body be trusted?
Who do Jehovah's Witnesses believe introduced independent thinking?
What religion accommodates members who question its teachings?
What religion encourages its adherents to think critically?
What religion treats those who want to engage in independent thinking in a loving way?
What religion wouldn't think of expelling someone merely because they have questions about what the church teaches?

context: Doctrines of <b5_0><b6_0><b7_0><b8_0>Jehovah's Witnesses<b8_0/><b7_0/><b6_0/><b5_0/> are established by <a0_0>the Governing Body<a0_0/>. The religion does not tolerate <a1_0>dissent<a1_0/> over doctrines and practices; members who openly disagree with the religion's teachings are <a2_0>expelled and shunned<a2_0/>. Witness publications strongly discourage followers from questioning doctrine and counsel received from the Governing Body, reasoning that it is to be trusted as <a3_0>part of "God's organization"<a3_0/>. It also warns members to "avoid independent thinking", claiming such thinking "was introduced by <a4_0>Satan the Devil<a4_0/>" and would "cause division". Those who openly disagree with official teachings are condemned as "apostates" who are "mentally diseased".
